awd_titl_txt: New Insights from Legacy Archaeology Collections
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers from the University of California, Berkeley and San Francisco State University will undertake the study of impressive mounds constructed of shell and other materials by people worldwide in many riverine and coastal places. For more than 5000 years, indigenous groups created coastal landscapes dominated by such artificial hills built from many tons of shellfish  that left a legacy from which to study social and environmental change over millennia. Archaeology can provide new insights about how and why people built these mounded landscapes where shell was used to build architectural features (pyramids, ridges, walkways, plazas), to create mortuary mounds, and to construct elevated villages. A major challenge in the study of shell mounds is that many have been heavily damaged by the rapid development of coastal areas worldwide. This project will develop and implement new and innovative methods for working with "legacy" museum collections recovered from sites before they were destroyed. Researchers will generate new insights about the nature of shell mounds, provide training for undergraduate and graduate students in archaeological and museum methods, and contribute to a public outreach program highlighting the significant cultural heritage of these places. A centerpiece of this project will be the development of a public outreach program about shell mounds in collaboration with local tribes, community members, museums, and city governments.  

Members of the research team will engender a better understanding of the people who built mounded landscapes using new techniques to highlight their economies, social organizations,  and mortuary/ceremonial practices. The research will involve the fine-grained reanalysis of museum collections recovered from sites now destroyed employing new methods for recovering botanical remains and starch grains, identifying small animal bones using molecular fingerprinting, investigating "micro" artifacts, dating materials using state-of-the art techniques, and employing computer-generated mapping approaches.  Research will focus on the shell mounds in the greater San Francisco Bay Area (northern California) where hundreds of sites once dotted the shoreline before their destruction by urban development.  The West Berkeley shell mound, one of the largest and oldest of these mounds, will serve as a test case.  Archaeological materials from the 1950s excavation (before its destruction) now curated in the Phoebe A. Hearst Museum of Anthropology provide an exceptional opportunity for implementing new analytical approaches for the study of museum objects and soils, for training students, and for evaluating the history of this important place over more than 4000 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Researchers from the University of California, Berkeley and San Francisco State University undertook a detailed study of the West Berkeley Shell Mound, one of the oldest and largest of the more than 425 shell mounds that once ringed the San Francisco Bay.  Unfortunately, most of these iconic sites have been heavily impacted by historic urban development.  The West Berkeley Shell Mound once consisted of an impressive mound complex of shell, rocks, soil, ash, and other materials built up by Indigenous people over many generations. The primary field investigation of the site took place in the 1950s by U.C. Berkeley prior to the removal of the upper mound to make room for a factory. The purpose of this NSF project was to reanalyze the archaeological collections from the earlier excavation using state-of-the-art laboratory methods not available in the 1950s to provide new insights about the Native people who constructed the West Berkeley Shell Mound.

Our research team commenced the study of soil samples, artifacts, and animal remains from the excavated assemblage now curated in the Phoebe A. Hearst Museum of Anthropology at UC Berkeley.  The work involved the following activities. We fine screened (through nested geologic sieves: 4 mm, 2 mm, and 1 mm) and floated the curated soil samples to recover small-sized archaeological materials and charred plant remains.  We reanalyzed the curated artifacts and animal remains in the museum collection.  We investigated the possible existence of starch granules on groundstone tools (to identify the plants processed). We undertook the isotopic analysis of shellfish remains (to determine season of harvest). We selected ephemeral plant materials from the soil samples for 35 radiocarbon dates.  Finally, We digitized and coded  pertinent excavation information to produce a computer generated three-dimensional model of the site.

One significant finding of this study is that the original excavators in the 1950s overlooked many archaeological materials at the site. Like most other early excavations, screens were not systematically employed in the field to recover archaeological materials. Instead, the excavators relied on the commonly used “shovel broadcast” system that spread the contents of each shovelful of soil in front of the excavator who picked out those materials defined as archaeologically relevant for the day. What we found is that this “coarse-grained” recovery method missed many thousands of small-sized artifacts, small-bodied animal specimens, and charred plant remains. In employing a new method of museum research that integrated the findings from our fine screening and flotation of soil samples with the reanalysis of the curated materials from the earlier excavation, we generated a fuller, richer, and more complete understanding of the people and history of the West Berkeley Shell Mound. 

We found that people began building the mound complex about 6000 years ago when the San Francisco Bay was still taking shape during sea level rise. While the use of the mound changed somewhat over time, we discovered that the West Berkeley Shell Mound served as the first major fishing village on the San Francisco Bay – a place where communities lived, buried their dead, enacted ceremonies, conducted various domestic activities, and harvested a diverse range of maritime and terrestrial resources over many generations. We detected in the soil samples thousands of tiny bones of herring and other small schooling fish that had been overlooked by earlier researchers.  Our work suggests that the residents of West Berkeley probably used nets and boats to intensively harvest these small-bodied fish along with some large-bodied fish, such as sturgeons, bat rays, and salmon, as indicated by stone net weights and awls, needles and other worked bone artifacts that may have been used for making nets, cordage, and baskets.  The isotopic analysis indicates that the residents harvested extensive volumes of mussels and clams in the late fall and early spring, along with oysters and other shellfish species. We also detected various kinds of edible nuts and seeds that they collected from nearby woodlands and grasslands that had not been previously identified. An intriguing finding was the detection of macrobotanical remains from the harvesting of grassland habitats about 700-1000 CE – a time when coastal prairies elsewhere in the greater San Francisco Bay Area appear to have been enhanced by Indigenous stewardship practices involving cultural burning and other activities.  

In sum, the NSF project provided an exceptional opportunity for implementing new analytical approaches to the study of legacy collections of museum objects and curated soils that exponential expanded our understanding of the history and significance of the West Berkeley Shell Mound over more than 6000 years. It also facilitate the training of a team of undergraduate and graduate students in archaeological and museum research methods.
